numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I noticed a pattern in admissions.
2. Legacy applicants were admitted at a significantly higher rate than non-legacy applicants.
3. This difference existed regardless of income.
4. Even at the highest income level, the likelihood of admission was slightly more than 2 times.
5. This likelihood was lower than the likelihood for legacy applicants whose parents had a 99.9 income percentile.
6. I wonder how income affects the school's admission decisions.
7. I ask whether the admission of many legacy students suggests nepotism.
8. I ask what makes a legacy student a better applicant than a non-legacy student.
9. I ask whether the actions of alumni at these schools affect the admission of their children.
10. I come from an urban community.
11. Many of my classmates are not legacy students.
12. Many parents of my classmates are not alumni of these schools.
13. This situation makes admission harder for these classmates.
15. Legacy status is out of the control of these classmates.
16. Parental or guardian income is out of the control of these classmates.
17. The headline is: Nepotism at Ivy, Advantages Not Even Money Could Buy!
